Please call 877-525-6397 to upgrade your subscription. × Register for more free articles Stay logged in to skip the surveys Log in Sign up {{featured_button_text}} Tense protests over the death of George Floyd and other police killings of black men grew Saturday from Tulsa to Los Angeles, with police cars set ablaze and reports of injuries mounting on all sides as the country lurched toward another night of unrest after months of coronavirus lockdowns. The protests, which began in Minneapolis following Floyd's death Monday after a police officer pressed a knee on his neck for more than eight minutes, have left parts of the city a grid of broken windows, burned-out buildings and ransacked stores. The unrest has since become a national phenomenon as protesters decry years of deaths at police hands. The large crowds involved, with many people not wearing masks or social distancing, raised concerns among health experts about the potential for helping spread the coronavirus pandemic at a time when overall deaths are on the decline nationwide and much of the country is in the process of reopening society and the economy. After a tumultuous Friday night, racially diverse crowds took to the streets again for mostly peaceful demonstrations in dozens of cities from coast to coast. The previous day's protests also started calmly, but many descended into violence later in the day. CNN reporter: This looks like a war zone CNN reporter Kyung Lah likened a prominent shopping area in Los Angeles to a war zone as protesters laid waste to the area as part of a protes…

title: National Guard called in to quell violence in Los Angeles
text: San Francisco Police Chief Bill Scott said he understood why protesters are angry at police. But he warned that if anyone assaulted officers, “we will not tolerate that.” In nearby Oakland, which was wracked by violence Friday night that left 13 officers injured, authorities declared an unlawful demonstration near City Hall late Saturday. Protesters lit a dumpster on fire in the middle of an intersection and police launched tear gas into a crowd. In Emeryville, just east of San Francisco, Mayor Christian Patz said Target, Best Buy and other box stores were burglarized, with thieves stealing electronics and other items. Stores in the city closed early Saturday as part of a shelter-in-place order following violent protests in nearby Oakland the night before. “It’s an explosion of the frustration of the people in the community,” Patz said, “If we’re going to ask people to stay within the bounds of the law, we’re going to have to show that the law applies to everyone." In Santa Ana, south of Los Angeles, hundreds of demonstrators converged on the police station, throwing objects and setting off firecrackers as police used tear gas to push them back.

title: WATCH: Authorities release footage from Sunday night civil unrest near Empire Mall
text: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) — Authorities in Sioux Falls are asking the public to help identify people responsible for damage from Sunday night’s events at the Empire Mall. You can see video authorities shared with media members in the video player above. The Sioux Falls Police Department is asking anyone with information on criminal activity to report it to police at (605) 367-7212 or anonymous at Crime Stoppers at (605) 367-7007.

title: A sheriff put down his baton to listen to protesters. They chanted 'walk with us,' so he did
text: Genesee County Sheriff Chris Swanson spoke with demonstrators who were met by police officers in riot gear and then joined the protest, according to CNN affiliate WEYI. A Michigan sheriff joined protesters in Flint Township on Saturday, putting down his weapon and saying, "I want to make this a parade, not a protest." Genesee County Sheriff Chris Swanson spoke with demonstrators who were met by police officers in riot gear, local affiliate WEYI reported. "The only reason we're here is to make sure that you got a voice -- that's it," Swanson said in video clips shown on Twitter. "These cops love you -- that cop over there hugs people," he said, pointing to an officer. He was speaking to the crowd protesting police brutality and the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. He smiled and high-fived people in the crowd, who responded by chanting, "walk with us!" So, he did. "Let's go, let's go," Swanson said as he and the cheering crowd proceeded. "Where do you want to walk? We'll walk all night."

title: US sends Brazil malaria drug unproven for COVID-19 treatment
text: × Help support our COVID-19 coverage We're providing access to COVID-19 articles for free. Please help support our work by subscribing or signing up for an account. Already a subscriber? Log in. Log in Sign up Become a Member WASHINGTON (AP) — The U.S. has sent to Brazil more than 2 million doses of a malaria drug touted by President Donald Trump as potentially protecting against and treating the coronavirus, even though scientific evidence has not backed up those uses. No large, rigorous scientific studies have found the drug, hydroxychloroquine, safe or effective for preventing or treating COVID-19, and some smaller studies have indicated worse outcomes from those taking the drug. Brazil, now Latin America’s hardest-hit country, continues to see a surge in virus cases, and last week Trump announced that the U.S. was restricting travel from the country to prevent travelers from spreading the virus in the U.S. In a joint statement with the Brazilian government on Sunday, the White House said the doses of hydroxychloroquine had been sent to Brazil as a prophylactic for front-line health workers and as a therapeutic for those who may come down with the virus. The White House said it was also delivering 1,000 ventilators to Brazil. Trump revealed in May that he took a two-week course of the drug to protect against the coronavirus, despite warnings from his own government that it should only be administered for COVID-19 in a hospital or research setting due to potentially fatal side effects.

title: Trump briefly taken to underground bunker during Friday's White House protests
text: Protesters pushed hard enough a few times that officers had to walk away with what appeared to be minor injuries. At one point, the agents responded to aggressive pushing and yelling by using pepper spray on the protesters. Throughout the night, protesters could be heard chanting their support for Floyd, an unarmed black man who died after being pinned down by a white police officer, and their dislike of Trump. The protest, which began around 10 p.m. ET, Friday night outside the White House, had mostly quieted down by 3:30 a.m. ET, Saturday morning. The crowd thinned out and Secret Service officers were able to expand their perimeter and barriers around Lafayette Park across from the White House. Six arrests were made during the protests, the Secret Service confirmed in a statement Saturday afternoon. The President on Thursday had used the threat of police retaliation and military intervention in Minnesota where protests turned violent and destructive -- saying on Twitter that "when the looting starts, the shooting starts." Trump's weekend tweets also invoked imagery tied to brutal civil rights-era police tactics. Now, a serious divide has emerged among the President's top allies and advisers over how the President should address several nights of protests and riots.

title: Protests flare again in US; with calls to end police violence also come pleas to end fires, looting
text: × Loading&hellp; {{title}} {{start_at_rate}} {{format_dollars}} {{start_price}} {{format_cents}} {{term}} {{promotional_format_dollars}}{{promotional_price}}{{promotional_format_cents}} {{term}} {{html}} Thanks for being a subscriber. Sorry, your subscription does not include this content. Please call 877-525-6397 to upgrade your subscription. × Register for more free articles Stay logged in to skip the surveys Log in Sign up {{featured_button_text}} Protesters took to the streets across America again Sunday, with violence flaring in pockets of largely peaceful demonstrations fueled by the killings of black people at the hands of police. A truck driver drove into demonstrators in Minneapolis nearly a week after George Floyd died there after pleading for air as an officer pressed a knee into his neck. Protests sprang up from Boston to San Francisco, with people stealing from stores in broad daylight in Philadelphia, cities across California and elsewhere. In Minneapolis, the tanker truck sped into a peaceful crowd of thousands on a closed highway, but no one appeared to have been hit, authorities said. The Minnesota State Patrol said on Twitter that the driver's actions were "very disturbing" and he was arrested. Protesters swarmed the truck and jumped on the hood, even as it kept moving. Police then came in force to clear the highway in the city where violence erupted after the death last week of Floyd, who was black. The protests quickly spread to dozens of cities large and small, and have lasted for days. The officer who pressed his knee onto Floyd's neck for several minutes has been charged with murder, but protesters demand the other three officers at the scene be prosecuted. All four were fired.

title: One city, two protests: Floyd protest deemed unlawful, stay-at home protest not
text: In late April, about a month in to Newsom's stay-at-home order, a heat wave hit Southern California. In Los Angeles County, beaches remained closed. But Ventura and Orange Counties allowed citizens to go to the beach, as long as they adhered to a patchwork of guidelines and restrictions, including keeping parking lots closed to discourage outside visitors and limit crowds. The following week, he ordered the closure of Orange County beaches. Orange County officials blamed "misleading photographs" for Newsom's decision, saying a telephoto lens made it look like there were more people on the beach than there were in reality. On May 1, between 2,500 and 3,000 people attended protests over Newsom's order, according to Huntington Beach Police Chief Robert Handy. While the beach was technically closed, officers did not appear to be enforcing the governor's new closure order, CNN reported. Out of sight from protesters, riot patrol officers on horseback staged under the Huntington Beach Pier, with one officer telling CNN they were there "just in case."

title: Violence and pandemic shake America as it heads into new week
text: The demonstrations were sparked by the death of George Floyd, a black man who pleaded for air as an officer pressed a knee into his neck. Floyd's death in Minneapolis came after tensions had already flared after two white men were arrested in May for the February shooting death of black jogger Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia, and the Louisville police shooting death of Breonna Taylor in her home in March. The scale of the coast-to-coast protests rivaled the historic demonstrations of the civil rights and Vietnam War eras. "They keep killing our people. I'm so sick and tired of it," said Mahira Louis, 15, who was at a Boston protest with her mother Sunday, leading chants of "George Floyd, say his name." Tensions rose Sunday outside the White House, the scene of three days of demonstrations, where police fired tear gas and stun grenades into a crowd of more than 1,000 chanting protesters across the street in Lafayette Park. The crowd ran, piling up road signs and plastic barriers to light a raging fire in a nearby street. Some pulled an American flag from a building and threw it into the blaze. A building in the park with bathrooms and a maintenance office went up in flames.

title: Noem activates National Guard after protests turn violent
text: × Loading&hellp; {{title}} {{start_at_rate}} {{format_dollars}} {{start_price}} {{format_cents}} {{term}} {{promotional_format_dollars}}{{promotional_price}}{{promotional_format_cents}} {{term}} {{html}} Thanks for being a subscriber. Sorry, your subscription does not include this content. Please call 877-525-6397 to upgrade your subscription. × Register for more free articles Stay logged in to skip the surveys Log in Sign up {{featured_button_text}} SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (AP) — South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem on Monday said she is keeping the National Guard deployed and ready to step in if demonstrations over the death of George Floyd turn violent. The Republican governor deployed National Guard troops to the scene of a violent protest in Sioux Falls on Sunday night after stores were vandalized and protesters hurled rocks at police. Her comments came shortly after President Donald Trump told governors in a video conference call they “look like fools” for not deploying more National Guard members to demonstrations across the country. Noem said she would keep the National Guard “pre-staged” nearby protests planned in other cities across the state. “Rioting and looting will not be tolerated,” she said. The governor said there was a “stark contrast” between the peaceful protest in downtown Sioux Falls and the vandalism that occurred during the night near the city’s largest mall. Sioux Falls police are investigating vandalism at several businesses.

title: George Floyd family to release results of own autopsy
text: Melinek said it's not unusual for different pathologists to reach different determinations, given that they may be looking at different information and that they've had different experiences and training. Under the law, a medical examiner determines the cause and manner of death, but it's up to prosecutors to decide whether criminal charges are warranted. The term homicide means only that a person's death was caused by another person. Chauvin, who was also charged with manslaughter, is being held in a state prison. The other three officers on scene, like Chauvin, were fired the day after the incident but have not been charged. The head of the Minneapolis police union said in a letter to members that the officers were fired without due process and labor attorneys are fighting for their jobs. Lt. Bob Kroll, the union president, also criticized city leadership, saying a lack of support is to blame for the days of sometimes violent protests. When asked to respond, Mayor Jacob Frey said Kroll's opposition to reform and lack of empathy for the community has undermined trust in the police.

title: Convulsing in protest, US cities brace for more unrest
Biden meets with black leaders at local church amid unrest
text: “To see the president of the United States say that he's going to send the military into our communities but hadn't mentioned sending a single dime of support into our communities, speaks to where we are in America,” said Atlanta Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms. Much of Biden's campaign strategy centers on trying to draw a contrast with Trump on temperament and values. He has called the White House contest a battle for the soul of the nation and has been particularly forceful in condemning Trump's handling of moments of racial tension. In an election that is likely to be a referendum on the sitting president, some Biden aides say privately that the best plan may be to let Trump do himself in. Yet there is also a recognition that Biden needs to do more than simply wait for voters who may be turned off by Trump to turn toward him. Some Democrats who have criticized Biden for not being more visible during the onset of the coronavirus said he is making the right moves now. “I’m sure they have some reluctance, understandably, right now to politicize it. That's not who he is," said Democratic strategist James Carville. “There might be a time for eloquence, but I think that simplicity is eloquence right now.”

title: Live at 1: Gov. Kristi Noem to speak in Sioux Falls after night of unrest
text: Gov. Kristi Noem said she is open to solutions in light of the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody and the subsequent protests in the last week. She said on Monday that she has asked her team to find possible legislative changes and called for everyone to find solutions for policies and policing. She said having conversations will put the state on a better path for every resident to have an equal change at success. Noem didn't give specific details of state laws that could be changed, but she said her administration has been considering possible changes that facilitate fairness, law and order and allowing people to have their voices heard. "We've been having this conversation about race and inequality for decades in this country and a lot of politicians and public figures stand up and talk and frankly, I'm more interested in what we can do," Noem said. Buy Photo Gov. Kristi Noem surveys the damage done to vehicles after Sunday's protests turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 at the School for the Deaf in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Rep. Linda Duba, a Democrat who represents central Sioux Falls, welcomed Noem's interest in taking a look at potential changes to state laws on Monday. Duba said she wants the organizers of Sunday's march to be part of the conversation. She said there's been no talk among legislators about potential changes to state laws since the events in Minneapolis began last week. However, Duba said, state laws are "only as good as the paper it's written on. It's just words on a page. There's got to be accountability on all sides of the equation and without accountability, we make no change." National Guard activated Meanwhile, the South Dakota National Guard remains on active status in Sioux Falls after a night of clashes between law enforcement and protesters on Sunday, but the Guard's numbers and locations may change based on actions elsewhere in the state, Noem said. Noem noted that other protests are planned elsewhere in South Dakota and the state plans to be prepared with resources staged like they were in Sioux Falls on Sunday. The full South Dakota National Guard is available to be activated and the assessment is ongoing of where they should be deployed based on skills and equipment, Noem said. Noem activated the South Dakota National Guard in Sioux Falls on Sunday night when protesters began breaking into stores and throwing rocks at police. The National Guard was deployed to downtown Sioux Falls, which freed up local authorities downtown to respond to the Empire Mall area. The National Guard were in place to secure locations and keep people safe, Noem said on Sunday night. Ellis column: On night filled with nervous energy and flashes of violence, disaster was averted About 70 Guard members were in Sioux Falls. Twenty-six members are from the 114th Fighter Wing of the Sioux Falls-based Air National Guard and 44 members from the 235th Army National Guard, which is a military police unit, according to Noem. Noem said she trusts South Dakotans to do the right thing and the vast majority of residents made the right decision on Sunday night. The peaceful protest on Sunday honored the memory of Floyd while recognizing that everyone needs to take action to ensure people are treated fairly, Noem said. However, that agenda changed on Sunday night, she said. "Today, the conversation isn't about peaceful protest. It's about the violence that happened last night," Noem said. Duba attended the march on Sunday, but saw the clashes between police and protesters unfold on TV. She said the activation of the National Guard was "probably a good idea." It was appropriate that Sioux Falls police weren't in riot gear during the march, but riot gear was appropriate during the events in the Empire Mall area later on Sunday night, she said. "The violence that I saw on TV was upsetting to me and frustrating after the time that I spent for an hour and a half downtown Sioux Falls," she said. "We're better than this, Sioux Falls, and I think a lot of folks who went to clean up showed that we're better than this." Buy Photo Jeff Halberstadt speaks with Gov. Kristi Noem after damage was done to his business when Sunday's protests turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 at Halberstadt's in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Law enforcement was attacked with rocks and business owners were victimized when stores were looted and vandalized, Noem said. State vehicles used to bring deaf and hard-of-hearing children to appointments were damaged and those families won't have that service available now, she said. "These aren't protesters that did these actions last night. These are violent criminals. Do not call them protesters," she said. Noem's new riot boosting law goes into effect July 1. Noem said that law involves civil penalties instead of criminal activities and the activities on Sunday night were criminal, she said. She said she supports people's right to peacefully protest, but residents got a "glimpse" of what can happen when a peaceful protest becomes violent. "That was necessary legislation to make sure that we have tools ready when they are required to make sure that we're being fair and just and we're facilitating peaceful protests," Noem said. Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken thanked the state for the support it provided on Sunday night in the press conference with Noem, Public Safety Secretary Craig Price and Brig. Gen. Russ Walz, the assistant adjutant general of the South Dakota Air National Guard. A "whole lot of behind-the-scenes legwork" went on in recent days to ensure the city had proper resources to respond to protesters' actions on Sunday night, TenHaken said. He said Sioux Falls' priority is ensuring that safety continues, but the city is ready to help out other communities in the state if the need arises. More: TenHaken: 'There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls' ACLU calls for changes On Monday, the American Civil Liberties Union of South Dakota called on South Dakota lawmakers and stakeholders to create policies that "break down the unchecked systemic racism." The frustration and anger seen in protests across the country in the last week are the result of past promises for reform going unfulfilled and an ever-growing list of people of color who have been killed by police, according to the ACLU. Heather Smith, executive director of the ACLU of South Dakota, said they're troubled by the continued insistence that "these things don't happen in South Dakota." Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night "Invariably, people of color in South Dakota face systemic barriers to education, health care, employment and justice," Smith said in a statement. There must be real accountability from law enforcement, the legal system and elected officials to move from outrage to healing, she said. "There must be healing and a fundamental shift in our state's priorities. It will take all of us acknowledging and fighting against racism to prevent the next tragic incident from happening here," she said. title: Here's what businesses have reported damage in Empire Mall area
text: CLOSE Several businesses in western Sioux Falls along the 41st Street and Louise Avenue corridor were vandalized after protests turned violent in the Empire Mall area on Sunday night. And while police are still working to determine the value of damage and stolen property, early calculations show more than $75,000 worth of destruction and theft in the city in the final hours of the weekend. "We're looking for everybody," said police spokesman Sam Clemens at the Tuesday morning police briefing. "Everybody that was committing a crime that night, we're looking for them." Here's a list of businesses near 41st Street and Louise Avenue reporting damage and stolen items: Chico's on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry at an estimated $10,000 loss on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry at an estimated $10,000 loss Halberstadts on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported windows broken and items taken, including a mannequin. Estimated damage is at $8,000. on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported windows broken and items taken, including a mannequin. Estimated damage is at $8,000. Riddle's Jewelry on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry. Estimated damage and stolen items is at $45,000. on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry. Estimated damage and stolen items is at $45,000. Starbucks on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows. Estimated damage $5,000. on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows. Estimated damage $5,000. Liberty National Bank at 3520 South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and damaged doors. Estimated damage $1,000. Haegle's Western Wear & Tack at 2800 West 41st Street reported a broken window. Estimated damage $500. at 2800 West 41st Street reported a broken window. Estimated damage $500. Rudolph's Shoe Mart at 3405 South Louise reported multiple windows broken and doors damaged. Damage estimated at $5,000. at 3405 South Louise reported multiple windows broken and doors damaged. Damage estimated at $5,000. TJ Maxx at 3401 South Louise Avenue had windows broken. A group of teenagers were cleaning up glass at the scene on Monday morning, according to an Argus Leader reporter on scene. Police are working with the store to identify stolen items and obtain surveillance video. at 3401 South Louise Avenue had windows broken. A group of teenagers were cleaning up glass at the scene on Monday morning, according to an Argus Leader reporter on scene. Police are working with the store to identify stolen items and obtain surveillance video. The Empire Mall had some windows broken on the northeast side of the building, including at JC Penney and Evereve . Squad cars in the area were also damaged by thrown rocks and vandalized during the riot. Police are still determining damage and loss values. had some windows broken on the northeast side of the building, including at . Squad cars in the area were also damaged by thrown rocks and vandalized during the riot. Police are still determining damage and loss values. Dakota News Now reported that one of its news vehicle had a window broken out while reporters covered the incident at the Empire Mall. While most of the damage was at businesses near the Empire Mall, there were also reports of damage in other areas of the city. Fleet Farm in northern Sioux Falls at 3035 West Fleet Street reported broken doors and stolen guns. in northern Sioux Falls at 3035 West Fleet Street reported broken doors and stolen guns. Verizon Wireless at 41st Street and Kiwanis Avenue reported broken windows and several stolen items. Police are working to get a list of stolen items. Shell casings were found in the parking lot. at 41st Street and Kiwanis Avenue reported broken windows and several stolen items. Police are working to get a list of stolen items. Shell casings were found in the parking lot. Arthur Johnson Shoes on the corner of 41st Street and Kiwanis Avenue reported broken windows. on the corner of 41st Street and Kiwanis Avenue reported broken windows. Keiser Family Chiropractic on the corner of 49th Street and Valhalla Boulevard just south of the Empire Mall reported that its sign was damaged. on the corner of 49th Street and Valhalla Boulevard just south of the Empire Mall reported that its sign was damaged. Beds and Beds at 41st Street and Prairie Avenue reported damaged windows. Have businesses to add? title: TenHaken: 'There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls'
text: CLOSE In an emotional press conference prior to Monday morning's police briefing, Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken said there would be accountability for those who committed more than $75,000 worth vandalism and theft on Sunday night following the March for George Floyd. TenHaken, standing in front of a monitor that showed surveillance footage of people breaking store windows and vandalizing police cars, opened with positive remarks about the crowd that gathered at Van Eps Park for a peaceful demonstration. But once a group broke off from that protest and made it to the Empire Mall, he said, "the day deteriorated into lawlessness." A rock taken from the scene where unrest unfolded Sunday evening was placed on the podium TenHaken stood behind. He estimated it weighed between five and seven pounds, not unlike others that were thrown at police officers in the mall parking lot. "There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls," TenHaken said — and finding the culprits starts with the video, photos and license plates that law enforcement has collected. Some of that evidence will be shared with the public in hopes of finding those who police have not yet been able to identify. "If you want to do the right thing," he said, "and you know you committed crimes last night, you should turn yourself into the police department." Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night Police Chief Matt Burns said the rioting, violence and looting made for "a tough night last night in our city." Police had a detailed plan in place to stand beside the peaceful protesters, and provide a safe space for them to exercise their First Amendment rights, he said. But the night's events "at a certain point that turned in a dark way," Burns said. Only minor injuries were reported among Sioux Falls cops, with Burns noting one struck in the hand by a rock. Several police vehicles were damaged or tagged with graffiti, he said. Buy Photo People face a line of armed police officers shouting "hands up, don't shoot" on Sunday, May 31, in Sioux Falls. (Photo: Erin Bormett / Argus Leader) Authorities make two arrests Two people were arrested during the evening, he said, both by Lincoln County deputies who had been asked to provide assistance. One of them had an Omaha address. It wasn't clear how many of the protesters were from out of state. Burns said the police department was aware of rumors that a group of agitators were being bused in from Fargo, which experienced violent demonstrations the night prior, but that appeared to be a "false flag." "We don't know that that materialized," he said. The mayor said it's clear the primary suspects involved in the rock throwing, vandalism and looting were teenagers from Sioux Falls. "I recognize kids on this video," he said. "I saw them wearing shirts of local sports leagues and local high schools." TenHaken said repeatedly that he was particularly troubled by the involvement of juveniles in the violence, saying that "we cannot afford to have a lost generation in our city." Buy Photo A lone protester holds a sign in a cloud of tear gas on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Pointedly driving a finger into the podium, TenHaken said parents needed to take responsibility as well. "You need to be a parent in this city. You need to step up and parent these kids." More: While some threw rocks at police and The Empire Mall, others pleaded with them to stop Read or Share this story: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/06/01/sioux-falls-empire-mall-protests-george-floyd-city-response/5308588002/

The National Guard was deployed to downtown Sioux Falls, which freed up local authorities downtown to respond to the Empire Mall area. The National Guard were in place to secure locations and keep people safe, Noem said on Sunday night. Ellis column: On night filled with nervous energy and flashes of violence, disaster was averted About 70 Guard members were in Sioux Falls. Twenty-six members are from the 114th Fighter Wing of the Sioux Falls-based Air National Guard and 44 members from the 235th Army National Guard, which is a military police unit, according to Noem. Noem said she trusts South Dakotans to do the right thing and the vast majority of residents made the right decision on Sunday night. The peaceful protest on Sunday honored the memory of Floyd while recognizing that everyone needs to take action to ensure people are treated fairly, Noem said. However, that agenda changed on Sunday night, she said. "Today, the conversation isn't about peaceful protest. It's about the violence that happened last night," Noem said. Duba attended the march on Sunday, but saw the clashes between police and protesters unfold on TV. She said the activation of the National Guard was "probably a good idea." It was appropriate that Sioux Falls police weren't in riot gear during the march, but riot gear was appropriate during the events in the Empire Mall area later on Sunday night, she said. "The violence that I saw on TV was upsetting to me and frustrating after the time that I spent for an hour and a half downtown Sioux Falls," she said. "We're better than this, Sioux Falls, and I think a lot of folks who went to clean up showed that we're better than this." Buy Photo Jeff Halberstadt speaks with Gov. Kristi Noem after damage was done to his business when Sunday's protests turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 at Halberstadt's in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Law enforcement was attacked with rocks and business owners were victimized when stores were looted and vandalized, Noem said. State vehicles used to bring deaf and hard-of-hearing children to appointments were damaged and those families won't have that service available now, she said. "These aren't protesters that did these actions last night. These are violent criminals. Do not call them protesters," she said. Noem's new riot boosting law goes into effect July 1. Noem said that law involves civil penalties instead of criminal activities and the activities on Sunday night were criminal, she said. She said she supports people's right to peacefully protest, but residents got a "glimpse" of what can happen when a peaceful protest becomes violent. "That was necessary legislation to make sure that we have tools ready when they are required to make sure that we're being fair and just and we're facilitating peaceful protests," Noem said. Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken thanked the state for the support it provided on Sunday night in the press conference with Noem, Public Safety Secretary Craig Price and Brig. Gen. Russ Walz, the assistant adjutant general of the South Dakota Air National Guard. A "whole lot of behind-the-scenes legwork" went on in recent days to ensure the city had proper resources to respond to protesters' actions on Sunday night, TenHaken said. He said Sioux Falls' priority is ensuring that safety continues, but the city is ready to help out other communities in the state if the need arises. More: TenHaken: 'There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls' ACLU calls for changes On Monday, the American Civil Liberties Union of South Dakota called on South Dakota lawmakers and stakeholders to create policies that "break down the unchecked systemic racism." The frustration and anger seen in protests across the country in the last week are the result of past promises for reform going unfulfilled and an ever-growing list of people of color who have been killed by police, according to the ACLU. Heather Smith, executive director of the ACLU of South Dakota, said they're troubled by the continued insistence that "these things don't happen in South Dakota." Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night "Invariably, people of color in South Dakota face systemic barriers to education, health care, employment and justice," Smith said in a statement. There must be real accountability from law enforcement, the legal system and elected officials to move from outrage to healing, she said. "There must be healing and a fundamental shift in our state's priorities. It will take all of us acknowledging and fighting against racism to prevent the next tragic incident from happening here," she said. title: TenHaken: 'There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls'
text: CLOSE In an emotional press conference prior to Monday morning's police briefing, Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken said there would be accountability for those who committed more than $75,000 worth vandalism and theft on Sunday night following the March for George Floyd. TenHaken, standing in front of a monitor that showed surveillance footage of people breaking store windows and vandalizing police cars, opened with positive remarks about the crowd that gathered at Van Eps Park for a peaceful demonstration. But once a group broke off from that protest and made it to the Empire Mall, he said, "the day deteriorated into lawlessness." A rock taken from the scene where unrest unfolded Sunday evening was placed on the podium TenHaken stood behind. He estimated it weighed between five and seven pounds, not unlike others that were thrown at police officers in the mall parking lot. "There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls," TenHaken said — and finding the culprits starts with the video, photos and license plates that law enforcement has collected. Some of that evidence will be shared with the public in hopes of finding those who police have not yet been able to identify. "If you want to do the right thing," he said, "and you know you committed crimes last night, you should turn yourself into the police department." Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night Police Chief Matt Burns said the rioting, violence and looting made for "a tough night last night in our city." Police had a detailed plan in place to stand beside the peaceful protesters, and provide a safe space for them to exercise their First Amendment rights, he said. But the night's events "at a certain point that turned in a dark way," Burns said. Only minor injuries were reported among Sioux Falls cops, with Burns noting one struck in the hand by a rock. Several police vehicles were damaged or tagged with graffiti, he said. Buy Photo People face a line of armed police officers shouting "hands up, don't shoot" on Sunday, May 31, in Sioux Falls. (Photo: Erin Bormett / Argus Leader) Authorities make two arrests Two people were arrested during the evening, he said, both by Lincoln County deputies who had been asked to provide assistance. One of them had an Omaha address. It wasn't clear how many of the protesters were from out of state. Burns said the police department was aware of rumors that a group of agitators were being bused in from Fargo, which experienced violent demonstrations the night prior, but that appeared to be a "false flag." "We don't know that that materialized," he said. The mayor said it's clear the primary suspects involved in the rock throwing, vandalism and looting were teenagers from Sioux Falls. "I recognize kids on this video," he said. "I saw them wearing shirts of local sports leagues and local high schools." TenHaken said repeatedly that he was particularly troubled by the involvement of juveniles in the violence, saying that "we cannot afford to have a lost generation in our city." Buy Photo A lone protester holds a sign in a cloud of tear gas on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Pointedly driving a finger into the podium, TenHaken said parents needed to take responsibility as well. "You need to be a parent in this city. You need to step up and parent these kids." More: While some threw rocks at police and The Empire Mall, others pleaded with them to stop Read or Share this story: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/06/01/sioux-falls-empire-mall-protests-george-floyd-city-response/5308588002/

title: Live at 1: Gov. Kristi Noem to speak in Sioux Falls after night of unrest
text: Gov. Kristi Noem said she is open to solutions in light of the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody and the subsequent protests in the last week. She said on Monday that she has asked her team to find possible legislative changes and called for everyone to find solutions for policies and policing. She said having conversations will put the state on a better path for every resident to have an equal change at success. Noem didn't give specific details of state laws that could be changed, but she said her administration has been considering possible changes that facilitate fairness, law and order and allowing people to have their voices heard. "We've been having this conversation about race and inequality for decades in this country and a lot of politicians and public figures stand up and talk and frankly, I'm more interested in what we can do," Noem said. Buy Photo Gov. Kristi Noem surveys the damage done to vehicles after Sunday's protests turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 at the School for the Deaf in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Rep. Linda Duba, a Democrat who represents central Sioux Falls, welcomed Noem's interest in taking a look at potential changes to state laws on Monday. Duba said she wants the organizers of Sunday's march to be part of the conversation. She said there's been no talk among legislators about potential changes to state laws since the events in Minneapolis began last week. However, Duba said, state laws are "only as good as the paper it's written on. It's just words on a page. There's got to be accountability on all sides of the equation and without accountability, we make no change." National Guard activated Meanwhile, the South Dakota National Guard remains on active status in Sioux Falls after a night of clashes between law enforcement and protesters on Sunday, but the Guard's numbers and locations may change based on actions elsewhere in the state, Noem said. Noem noted that other protests are planned elsewhere in South Dakota and the state plans to be prepared with resources staged like they were in Sioux Falls on Sunday. The full South Dakota National Guard is available to be activated and the assessment is ongoing of where they should be deployed based on skills and equipment, Noem said. Noem activated the South Dakota National Guard in Sioux Falls on Sunday night when protesters began breaking into stores and throwing rocks at police. The National Guard was deployed to downtown Sioux Falls, which freed up local authorities downtown to respond to the Empire Mall area. The National Guard were in place to secure locations and keep people safe, Noem said on Sunday night. Twenty-six members are from the 114th Fighter Wing of the Sioux Falls-based Air National Guard and 44 members from the 235th Army National Guard, which is a military police unit, according to Noem. However, that agenda changed on Sunday night, she said. "Today, the conversation isn't about peaceful protest. It's about the violence that happened last night," Noem said. Duba attended the march on Sunday, but saw the clashes between police and protesters unfold on TV. She said the activation of the National Guard was "probably a good idea." It was appropriate that Sioux Falls police weren't in riot gear during the march, but riot gear was appropriate during the events in the Empire Mall area later on Sunday night, she said. "The violence that I saw on TV was upsetting to me and frustrating after the time that I spent for an hour and a half downtown Sioux Falls," she said. "We're better than this, Sioux Falls, and I think a lot of folks who went to clean up showed that we're better than this." Buy Photo Jeff Halberstadt speaks with Gov. Kristi Noem after damage was done to his business when Sunday's protests turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 at Halberstadt's in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Law enforcement was attacked with rocks and business owners were victimized when stores were looted and vandalized, Noem said. State vehicles used to bring deaf and hard-of-hearing children to appointments were damaged and those families won't have that service available now, she said. "These aren't protesters that did these actions last night. These are violent criminals. Do not call them protesters," she said. Noem's new riot boosting law goes into effect July 1. Noem said that law involves civil penalties instead of criminal activities and the activities on Sunday night were criminal, she said. She said she supports people's right to peacefully protest, but residents got a "glimpse" of what can happen when a peaceful protest becomes violent. "That was necessary legislation to make sure that we have tools ready when they are required to make sure that we're being fair and just and we're facilitating peaceful protests," Noem said. Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken thanked the state for the support it provided on Sunday night in the press conference with Noem, Public Safety Secretary Craig Price and Brig. Gen. Russ Walz, the assistant adjutant general of the South Dakota Air National Guard. A "whole lot of behind-the-scenes legwork" went on in recent days to ensure the city had proper resources to respond to protesters' actions on Sunday night, TenHaken said. He said Sioux Falls' priority is ensuring that safety continues, but the city is ready to help out other communities in the state if the need arises. The frustration and anger seen in protests across the country in the last week are the result of past promises for reform going unfulfilled and an ever-growing list of people of color who have been killed by police, according to the ACLU. Heather Smith, executive director of the ACLU of South Dakota, said they're troubled by the continued insistence that "these things don't happen in South Dakota." More: TenHaken: 'There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls' ACLU calls for changes On Monday, the American Civil Liberties Union of South Dakota called on South Dakota lawmakers and stakeholders to create policies that "break down the unchecked systemic racism." The frustration and anger seen in protests across the country in the last week are the result of past promises for reform going unfulfilled and an ever-growing list of people of color who have been killed by police, according to the ACLU. Heather Smith, executive director of the ACLU of South Dakota, said they're troubled by the continued insistence that "these things don't happen in South Dakota." Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night "Invariably, people of color in South Dakota face systemic barriers to education, health care, employment and justice," Smith said in a statement. There must be real accountability from law enforcement, the legal system and elected officials to move from outrage to healing, she said. "There must be healing and a fundamental shift in our state's priorities. It will take all of us acknowledging and fighting against racism to prevent the next tragic incident from happening here," she said. Read or Share this story: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/politics/2020/06/01/gov-kristi-noem-speak-sioux-falls-after-night-unrest/5307401002/

title: Here's what businesses have reported damage in Empire Mall area
text: CLOSE Several businesses in western Sioux Falls along the 41st Street and Louise Avenue corridor were vandalized after protests turned violent in the Empire Mall area on Sunday night. And while police are still working to determine the value of damage and stolen property, early calculations show more than $75,000 worth of destruction and theft in the city in the final hours of the weekend. "We're looking for everybody," said police spokesman Sam Clemens at the Tuesday morning police briefing. "Everybody that was committing a crime that night, we're looking for them." Here's a list of businesses near 41st Street and Louise Avenue reporting damage and stolen items: Chico's on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry at an estimated $10,000 loss on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry at an estimated $10,000 loss Halberstadts on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported windows broken and items taken, including a mannequin. Estimated damage is at $8,000. on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported windows broken and items taken, including a mannequin. Estimated damage is at $8,000. Riddle's Jewelry on the 3300 block of South Louise Avenue reported broken windows and stolen jewelry. The Empire Mall had some windows broken on the northeast side of the building, including at JC Penney and Evereve . title: World responds to protests sparked by George Floyd’s death
text: NA

title: Fox News reporter attacked, chased from demonstration
text: NEW YORK (AP) — A Fox News reporter was attacked and chased away by protesters outside of the White House early Saturday. News organizations covering demonstrations stemming from the death of George Floyd occasionally became targets themselves; windows were broken at CNN’s headquarters in Atlanta, and a TV reporter in Louisville, Kentucky, had what appeared to be pepper balls fired at her. The attack on Fox’s Leland Vittert included water and other objects thrown at him and his crew. He said Fox was specifically targeted by protesters who shouted obscenities at the news organization. A photographer for the Daily Caller captured video of the group chasing Vittert and his crew.

title: Protesters converge on White House for second straight day
text: WASHINGTON (AP) — Police fired pepper spray at demonstrators near the White House and the D.C. National Guard was called in as pockets of violence and vandalism erupted during a second straight night of protests. Sparking the demonstrations were the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis and President Donald Trump’s response to it. Hundreds of people converged on the White House and marched along the National Mall. Protesters dragged away barricades and used concrete for projectiles. A trash bin was set on fire. The D.C. demonstration was one of several around the country protesting Floyd’s death. Trump appeared to cheer on the tougher tactics being used by law enforcement to disperse protesters.

title: 'A lot of people are coming together': Sioux Falls businesses clean up after protests
text: CLOSE Dianne Horan was devastated when she saw shattered glass all the way to the back of her store. The store manager for Chico's was proud of Sioux Falls for its peaceful protesting Sunday afternoon, but was heartbroken to see the attitude change once the sun went down. "I didn't fathom Sioux Falls would have done this," said Horan, who was spending her Monday morning sweeping shattered glass from her store and sidewalk. Chico's, located in the strip mall on 41st Street and Louise Avenue, was one of a handful of businesses in the area with shattered windows, broken doors and stolen merchandise. Live at 1: Gov. Kristi Noem to speak in Sioux Falls after night of unrest A peaceful protest in downtown Sioux Falls in response to the death of George Floyd turned into a traffic-halting march across town and erupted into rock throwing and vandalism in the Empire Mall parking lot. Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken said in a live statement Sunday night he considered the events separately. "The peaceful protests were great," Horan said. "To go to this was so sad." Buy Photo Sioux Falls businesses clean up the aftermath of a protest turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Next door at Riddle's Jewelry, store manager Brent Reisenauer leaned on a glass-free door frame as repair crews taped his rock-damaged storefront windows and vacuumed remnants of what used to be a front door. No customer jewelry was taken, he said, but some display cases were broken and "minimal" merchandise was taken. There weren't any customer or employee injuries, he said. PROTESTS: Here's what businesses have reported damage in Empire Mall area "We're happy for that," said Reisenauer, who had been at the store for hours Monday morning cleaning up. While talking with the Argus Leader, a community member and longtime customer of Riddle's approached Reisnauer to check on him and offer support. Buy Photo Brent Reisenauer shakes hands with Jim Houk as they clean up the aftermath of a protest turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Workers sawed boards to fit a window completely robbed of its glass at Halberstadt's storefront. That was the majority of the damage, store manager Michael Gollo said. Right next door, Starbucks windows could be seen riddled with marks from rocks. Across the street, cleaning and repair crews were at TJ Maxx, which suffered damage to storefront windows. Staff there this morning referred the Argus Leader to the chain's media team, which has said it will respond to inquiries today. TENHAKEN: 'There's going to be accountability for what happened in Sioux Falls' The Empire Mall referred to the national Simon Malls media team, which has not responded to a request for comment regarding the damage done to numerous stores on the north side of the mall. Monday morning, a group of citizens gathered in the mall parking lot to clean up shattered glass and other liter. Buy Photo Dianne Horan, manager of Chico's, sweeps glass off the sidewalk after Sunday's protest turned violent on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Sioux Falls, S.D. (Photo: Abigail Dollins / Argus Leader) Because of the coronavirus, Chico's has been closed, Horan said, but the store was planning to open up Friday, a date she and employees were looking forward to. Horan was optimistic the doors would be fixed by then so she could still reopen, but said she'd first have to "shake out" all of the clothes to make sure glass shards weren't hiding in the fabrics. TIMELINE: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night Though disappointed in seeing all the damage, Horan said she was touched by the outpouring of support. A citizen stopped by and told her he had the license plate of someone who damaged the store. She planned on turning that information into police. As she was speaking with the Argus Leader, a community member approached Horan with a broom and trash bag and asked if she needed any help cleaning up. "A lot of people are coming together," she said. "Sioux Falls is known for that, for coming together." Email reporter Danielle Ferguson at dbferguson@argusleader.com, or follow on Twitter at @DaniFergs. Read or Share this story: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/06/01/sioux-falls-protest-riot-business-clean-up-after-destruction/5308874002/

title: Music industry calls for Black Out Tuesday amid unrest
text: Jay-Z and Beyonce watch Game 1 of an NBA basketball second-round playoff series between the Golden State Warriors and the New Orleans Pelicans in 2018. Several top record labels organized Black Out Tuesday on June 2, 2020 as riots erupted around the world sparked by George Floyd’s death as well as the killings of Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor. Musicians including Rihanna, Beyoncé, Taylor Swift, Lil Nas X, Demi Lovato, Post Malone and Harry Styles have spoken out following Floyd’s death and the worldwide riots. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez, File) NEW YORK (AP) — The music industry is planning to turn off the music and hold a day to reflect and implement change in response to the death of George Floyd and the killings of other black people. Several top record labels organized Black Out Tuesday as violent protests erupted around the world sparked by Floyd’s death as well as the killings of Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor. Music-based companies Live Nation and TikTok, as well as the Recording Academy, posted to social media that it planned to support and stand with the black community. “On Tuesday June 2nd, Columbia Records will observe ‘Black Out Tuesday,’” the Sony label home to Beyoncé, Bob Dylan, Adele and John Legend said in a statement. “This is not a day off. Instead, this is a day to reflect and figure out ways to move forward in solidarity.” “We continue to stand with the Black community, our staff, artists, and peers in the music industry,” the company continued. “Perhaps with the music off, we can truly listen.” Others that have joined Black Out Tuesday include the Sony imprints RCA Records and Epic Records; the Universal Music Group divisions Republic Records, Def Jam, UMG Nashville, Capitol Records and Island Records; and the Warner Music Group imprints Atlantic and Warner Records. Smaller, independent labels as well as music publishing companies and management firms have also signed on. UMG’s Interscope Geffen A&M said that in addition to joining Black Out Tuesday, the label home to Lady Gaga and Kendrick Lamar would not release music this week — the first label to do so. “Instead, IGA will contribute to organizations that help to bail out protesters exercising their right to peacefully assemble, aid lawyers working for systemic change and provide assistance to charities focused on creating economic empowerment in the Black community,” its statement read. IGA postponed new music releases MGK, 6lack, Dylan, Jessie Ware, Smokepurp, Lil Mosey, Billy Raffoul, Max Leone and more in coordination with their partners Alamo, LVRN, The Darkroom, Bad Boy and more. Musicians including Rihanna, Beyoncé, Taylor Swift, Lil Nas X, Demi Lovato, Post Malone and Harry Styles have spoken out following Floyd’s death and worldwide protests. Jay-Z released a statement late Sunday calling for Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison to prosecute those responsible for killing Floyd, a handcuffed black man who pleaded for air as a white police officer pressed a knee on his neck. “I, along with an entire country in pain, call upon AG Ellison to do the right thing and prosecute all those responsible for the murder of George Floyd to the fullest extent of the law. This is just a first step. I am more determined to fight for justice than any fight my would-be oppressors may have,” Jay-Z said. “I prevail on every politician, prosecutor and officer in the country to have the courage to do what is right. Have the courage to look at us as humans, dads, brothers, sisters and mothers in pain and look at yourselves.” Racial tensions were also running high after two white men were arrested in May in the February shooting death of black jogger Arbery in Georgia, and after Louisville, Kentucky, police shot Taylor to death in her home in March. The R&B duo Chloe x Halle, who will release their sophomore album “Ungodly Hour” on Friday, posted a cover of the classic civil rights anthem and protest song “We Shall Overcome” to Instagram. “This week has been very heavy for all of us. We’ve been trying to, not understand, because there’s no way to understand the terrible killings — we just have heavy hearts this week and are just trying to do everything we can to pray and lift each other up with our voices,” Halle said in an interview with The Associated Press. “With everything going on, we felt like music can be very healing, because it’s been that way for us in kind of keeping us sane during this time,” Chloe added. As much as we could, we just wanted to share our gift of song to even just lift spirits for even a few seconds.”

title: Early damage reports show most in 41st Street and South Louise Avenue area
text: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) — Sioux Falls Police are still gathering information but as of Monday morning, authorities say at least 10 businesses were damaged or had robberies during the civil unrest Sunday in the city. Sioux Falls Public Information Office Sam Clemens said owners of property with damage should contact police. Most of the reports come from the area near 41st Street and Louise Avenue and the Empire Mall. Damage includes an estimated $45,000 in theft and damage at Riddle’s Jewelry 609 W. 41st St. Mayor Paul TenHaken said in a morning briefing that many of the damaged and broken into businesses were either locally owned or South Dakota owned. TenHaken said evidence shows that much of the crime was committed by local high school youth. He and Sioux Falls Police Chief Matt Burns said those responsible for the crimes will be held accountable.

title: 'You can't discredit all young people': Sioux Falls teens help with protest cleanup
text: CLOSE A group of Sioux Falls teenagers were sad to see the peaceful Sunday afternoon protest they participated in turn into an unrecognizable night of destruction. They were more sad to hear city leaders say it was largely caused by their peers. They didn't want the last few hours of a Sunday night fueled by rock-throwing and tear gas to overshadow the potential good that could come from a peaceful march powered by a community known for coming together. So they came back to clean it up. The group of about 10 gathered at the Empire Mall around 8 a.m. Monday with trash bags and brooms in hand, ready to rid the parking lot of the shattered glass left by a crowd of people they say didn't represent the goal of the protest. Some were friends. Some just responded to a request to help clean up. Buy Photo A group of Sioux Falls teens help clean up the Empire Mall parking lot the morning of Monday, June 1, after they saw on social media the violence from Sunday night's protests. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) "You can't discredit all young people," said 17-year-old Katherine Escalante. "There were young people at the peaceful protest. There were people that walked miles that don't want (the violence) to be what we talk about." More: March organizers distance themselves from vandalism, clashes with police Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken said he was sad to see people under 18, some of whom he recognized, damaging businesses. "If you’re a parent and you don’t know where your kid is right now, and your kid is between the ages of 14 and 18, I have a pretty good idea of where a lot of them are," TenHaken said around 10 p.m. Sunday. "We have videos of your children committing criminal acts. Your kids need to get home. This is not a joke. This is serious." Buy Photo A group of Sioux Falls teens help clean up the Empire Mall parking lot the morning of Monday, June 1, after they saw on social media the damage from Sunday night's protests. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) TenHaken and organizers for Sunday afternoon's protest in response to the death of George Floyd were quick to call the events separate. Protesters started downtown around 5 p.m. Sunday, marched across Minnesota Avenue to 41st Street and ended at the Empire Mall. Within minutes of the crowd congregating in the parking lot, rocks were being thrown at police officers and some protesters who were part of the peaceful march formed a line in front of the officers. The situation evolved into more rock-throwing, and police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowds. More: Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night It was just as the chaos started to form that Abbie DeKramer decided she needed to go home. The 17-year-old was part of the peaceful march downtown and had walked the eight or so miles the group took to the mall parking lot. "I went back after things took a turn," she said. More: 'A lot of people are coming together': Sioux Falls businesses clean up after protests Buy Photo A group of Sioux Falls teens help clean up businesses the morning of Monday, June 1, after they saw on social media the damage done from Sunday night's protests. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) Dekramer, Escalante and their friends Monday morning moved from the Empire Mall parking lot to across the street, where other businesses were cleaning up the remnants of the night before. The teens swept glass from sidewalks in front of Halberstadt's and Starbucks before gathering again to discuss whether downtown needed cleaned up. Noah Greble, 17, who was out of town on Sunday but saw what happened on social media, said they also went to Falls Park to see if graffiti was still there. He asked if the Argus Leader reporters had heard if their building was OK. "I like the idea of peaceful protesting," he said. "Stealing stuff isn't doing anything." The Argus Leader last saw the group talking about their next move in the parking lot of Phillips Avenue Diner. "There's so much greatness that happened yesterday," DeKramer said. "We don't want that to be tainted." Email reporter Danielle Ferguson at dbferguson@argusleader.com, or follow on Twitter at @DaniFergs. Read or Share this story: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/06/01/sioux-falls-protests-teenagers-clean-up/5309394002/

The 17-year-old was part of the peaceful march downtown and had walked the eight or so miles the group took to the mall parking lot. "I went back after things took a turn," she said. More: 'A lot of people are coming together': Sioux Falls businesses clean up after protests Buy Photo A group of Sioux Falls teens help clean up businesses the morning of Monday, June 1, after they saw on social media the damage done from Sunday night's protests. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) Dekramer, Escalante and their friends Monday morning moved from the Empire Mall parking lot to across the street, where other businesses were cleaning up the remnants of the night before. The teens swept glass from sidewalks in front of Halberstadt's and Starbucks before gathering again to discuss whether downtown needed cleaned up. Noah Greble, 17, who was out of town on Sunday but saw what happened on social media, said they also went to Falls Park to see if graffiti was still there. He asked if the Argus Leader reporters had heard if their building was OK. "I like the idea of peaceful protesting," he said. "Stealing stuff isn't doing anything." The Argus Leader last saw the group talking about their next move in the parking lot of Phillips Avenue Diner. "There's so much greatness that happened yesterday," DeKramer said. "We don't want that to be tainted." Email reporter Danielle Ferguson at dbferguson@argusleader.com, or follow on Twitter at @DaniFergs. Read or Share this story: https://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2020/06/01/sioux-falls-protests-teenagers-clean-up/5309394002/

title: 'You can't discredit all young people': Sioux Falls teens help with protest cleanup
text: CLOSE A group of Sioux Falls teenagers were sad to see the peaceful Sunday afternoon protest they participated in turn into an unrecognizable night of destruction. They were more sad to hear city leaders say it was largely caused by their peers. They didn't want the last few hours of a Sunday night fueled by rock-throwing and tear gas to overshadow the potential good that could come from a peaceful march powered by a community known for coming together. So they came back to clean it up. The group of about 10 gathered at the Empire Mall around 8 a.m. Monday with trash bags and brooms in hand, ready to rid the parking lot of the shattered glass left by a crowd of people they say didn't represent the goal of the protest. Some were friends. Some just responded to a request to help clean up. Buy Photo A group of Sioux Falls teens help clean up the Empire Mall parking lot the morning of Monday, June 1, after they saw on social media the violence from Sunday night's protests. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) "You can't discredit all young people," said 17-year-old Katherine Escalante. "There were young people at the peaceful protest. There were people that walked miles that don't want (the violence) to be what we talk about." More: March organizers distance themselves from vandalism, clashes with police Sioux Falls Mayor Paul TenHaken said he was sad to see people under 18, some of whom he recognized, damaging businesses. "If you’re a parent and you don’t know where your kid is right now, and your kid is between the ages of 14 and 18, I have a pretty good idea of where a lot of them are," TenHaken said around 10 p.m. Sunday. "We have videos of your children committing criminal acts. Your kids need to get home. This is not a joke. This is serious." Buy Photo A group of Sioux Falls teens help clean up the Empire Mall parking lot the morning of Monday, June 1, after they saw on social media the damage from Sunday night's protests. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) TenHaken and organizers for Sunday afternoon's protest in response to the death of George Floyd were quick to call the events separate. Protesters started downtown around 5 p.m. Sunday, marched across Minnesota Avenue to 41st Street and ended at the Empire Mall. Within minutes of the crowd congregating in the parking lot, rocks were being thrown at police officers and some protesters who were part of the peaceful march formed a line in front of the officers. The situation evolved into more rock-throwing, and police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowds. More: Timeline: How protests unfolded in Sioux Falls on Sunday night It was just as the chaos started to form that Abbie DeKramer decided she needed to go home. The 17-year-old was part of the peaceful march downtown and had walked the eight or so miles the group took to the mall parking lot. "I went back after things took a turn," she said. (Photo: Danielle Ferguson/Argus Leader) Dekramer, Escalante and their friends Monday morning moved from the Empire Mall parking lot to across the street, where other businesses were cleaning up the remnants of the night before. The teens swept glass from sidewalks in front of Halberstadt's and Starbucks before gathering again to discuss whether downtown needed cleaned up. Noah Greble, 17, who was out of town on Sunday but saw what happened on social media, said they also went to Falls Park to see if graffiti was still there. He asked if the Argus Leader reporters had heard if their building was OK. "I like the idea of peaceful protesting," he said. "Stealing stuff isn't doing anything." The Argus Leader last saw the group talking about their next move in the parking lot of Phillips Avenue Diner. "There's so much greatness that happened yesterday," DeKramer said. "We don't want that to be tainted." Email reporter Danielle Ferguson at dbferguson@argusleader.com, or follow on Twitter at @DaniFergs. title: No new COVID-19 deaths reported in state
text: The number of confirmed coronavirus cases in South Dakota surpassed 5,000 on Monday while no new deaths were reported. COVID-19 cases increased by 41 on Monday for a total of 5,034 cases, according to the South Dakota Department of Health. That doesn’t include people who show symptoms or are asymptomatic but are not tested. A total of 1,533 test results were reported on Monday and the positive rate for coronavirus tests on Monday was 2.7%. The number of coronavirus deaths in South Dakota remained at 62. In Brown County, two new cases were confirmed Monday, pushing the total to 275 with 61 active. One person has died, 13 people have ever been hospitalized and there have been 1,532 negative tests. Of the 164 cases connected to DemKota Ranch Beef in Aberdeen, 134 have recovered, according to Clayton. The state has 1,069 active COVID-19 cases, according to the health department. Recoveries statewide increased to 3,903. The state health department noted 435 total people have been hospitalized during the pandemic, and 87 are currently hospitalized. There have been 40,627 negative tests. Coronavirus patients are occupying 4% of staffed hospital beds in the state while 54% of hospital beds are available, according to the health department. Coronavirus patients are occupying 6% of intensive care unit beds, and 47% of ICU beds are available. Six percent of ventilators are being used by coronavirus patients while 78% of the state’s ventilator capacity is available. The death of a coronavirus patient in the 20-29 age range was reported during the weekend. State Epidemiologist Josh Clayton said the person didn’t have any underlying medical conditions. Beadle County saw the largest increase in cases on Monday with 14 new cases, for a total of 275. Thirty-three of the 83 cases connected to the LSI Jack Link’s facility in Alpena have recovered, according to Clayton. The state is providing support to the company to hold mass testing events for its employees, one of which took place during the weekend and another that’s scheduled for later this week, Health Secretary Kim Malsam-Rysdon said. Mass testing A total of 4,077 nursing home residents and 6,023 nursing home staff have been tested for the coronavirus so far in the state’s plan to mass test long-term care facilities, according to Malsam-Rysdon. About 98% of nursing homes in communities with substantial community spread have completed the mass testing and nearly three-quarters of nursing homes in communities without substantial community spread have completed the mass testing, according to Malsam-Rysdon. The next mass testing will take place at assisted living facilities. Sioux Falls rally fallout It could take up to two weeks for new coronavirus cases to appear that were caused by the virus’ spread during Sunday’s protest in Sioux Falls, health officials said on Monday. More than 1,000 protesters gathered in Van Eps Park and marched through Sioux Falls on Sunday afternoon to support justice for George Floyd, a black man who died in Minneapolis police custody on May 25. Later in the night, protesters congregated at the Empire Mall, where they broke store windows and threw rocks at police. It takes two to 14 days for a new case to appear and could take upwards of two weeks for new coronavirus cases to appear that are the result of close contact during the protest, Clayton said. There is a risk of a spreading the coronavirus wherever people congregate, Clayton said. People should take precautions of staying 6 feet away from others and wear masks to reduce the chance of the virus spreading, he said. People will also be heading to the polls across South Dakota for the primary election on Tuesday. Clayton said health officials gave guidance on safety precautions at the polls and election officials also reviewed guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (visit www.aberdeennews.com)

title: 276 people arrested between Sunday, early Monday in Twin Cities
text: ST. PAUL -- Officers arrested 276 people between Sunday and early Monday, mostly for curfew violations, as people have continued taking to the streets over the death of George Floyd. Included in the number were 150 people who were arrested in the area of Washington Ave and Interstate 35W in Minneapolis on Saturday night after the 8 p.m. curfew, after law enforcement said they gave dispersal orders. During the arrests, officials found two bulletproof vests and four handguns hidden in nearby bushes, along with two handguns in people’s backpacks, according to the Minnesota Department of Public Safety. The Minneapolis fire department reported one new fire overnight, which was on the corner of 44th North and Penn avenues. Firefighters also responded throughout the night to several rekindled fires from earlier in the weekend. There were no fire-related injuries reported. In St. Paul, there was no major activity overnight. Law enforcement arrested 21 people for curfew violations in St. Paul — seven at the Capitol and 14 others elsewhere, according to the police department. “Even peaceful protesters who are breaking curfew are subject to arrest,” the Department of Public Safety tweeted Sunday night. “Please go home and stay there.” Sunday was the third night of an 8 p.m. curfew in St. Paul and Minneapolis. There have been peaceful protests since Floyd died in Minneapolis police custody last Monday, but also large-scale looting, arson and other violence. An officer, who has been terminated from the department, was charged with murder and manslaughter in Floyd’s death on Friday. Since the Minnesota Multi-Agency Command Center was set up Friday to respond to the unrest, there have been 481 arrests.
